6.text:
Well, it's wonderful to have such a large
and, hopefully, enthusiastic audience

12.text:
And it's wonderful for me to talk today. Yesterday
would have been my subject,

16.text:
Krystyna's, birthday. She would have been 105, 
but I don't think she would have admitted to it.

20.text:
So, it's nice to have an event to mark that,
really, as well.

24.text:
I am here to tell you the remarkable story
of this amazing war heroine, Krystyna Skarbek,

29.text:
better known, in this country at least, as
Christine Granville.

33.text:
And the book is called 'The Spy Who Loved'
because Christine was a very passionate woman.

41.text: She loved life in its wider sense.

42.text:
She loved adventure and adrenaline, and she 
loved men - she had two husbands

47.text:
and numerous lovers - and most of all she loved
freedom and independence:

53.text:
freedom for her country, Poland, and also
freedom for herself.

56.text: And those things were very intertwined for her.

59.text:
She was born a very well connected Polish countess. 
And she was a beauty queen before the war,

65.text:
and she was brought up used to adoration and
a sense of personal freedom.

70.text:
But because her mother was born Jewish she
was never really fully accepted in the

76.text:
higher echelons of Polish society and I think
she also grew up used to fighting her corner as well.

83.text:
Actually, these were all skills that became
very useful for her in her later life and career.

89.text:
I think Christine really always yearned to
be centre stage even when she was a child,

94.text:
which was rather denied her. And, actually,
I mentioned that to my mother and my mum said,

99.text:
'Centre stage - isn't that appropriate, darling!'
and I said, 'Yes mum, it is. Why is that, mum?'

103.text:
And she said, 'It's an anagram darling: secret
agent, centre stage.' And I said,

107.text:
'Oh, so it is!' So that's for you crossword lovers. 
And, of course, it was the Second World War

112.text:
that finally gave her what she wanted and
put her centre stage when she became Britain's

116.text:
first female special agent of the 
Second World War.

120.text:
Now, in 45 minutes it's impossible for me
to cover all of Christine's adventures and

125.text:
active service, and it's all, of course, in
the book. But I want to explain a few things.

129.text:
I want to say why Christine was so important.
I want to show some of her courage and her audacity

135.text:
in the three different theatres of the war
in which she volunteered and served.

139.text:
And I'm going to mention a little bit about
some of my own adventures

143.text: during my research for the book as well.

147.text:
So, perhaps it is appropriate for a secret
agent that the stories, the deceptions,

152.text:
the confusions that surround Christine's life
started with her birth. This is her baptism certificate,

160.text:
which I found in this beautiful leather-bound
volume in the parish archive

163.text:
near where she was born, or at least where
she grew up as a child. And somehow it survived

168.text:
despite a hundred years of wars and regime
changes. And I thought,

172.text:
'This is marvellous! I've got it in black
and white from the start and I'm going to

174.text: get all my facts in a row,

176.text:
that's what we want.' But it's not like that
at all, unfortunately.

179.text:
It's dated 1913 - in fact it's got two different
dates on it - but I know that Christine was

185.text:
born on 1 May 1908 and neither of those dates
are right for her birth year. And it's written

192.text:
in Russian, not Polish, although she was born
in Warsaw. But that's more easy to understand

197.text:
because, of course, Warsaw in 1908 was part
of the greater Russian Empire as it was at the time.

202.text:
So, I just thought it was quite ironic: Christine
was born on Labour Day - the traditional socialist

207.text:
or communist holiday - into this family of
aristocratic patriots, belonging to a country

211.text:
that wouldn't even exist again until she was
10 years old.

216.text:
So, this is her death certificate - we're
fast-forwarding here. As you can see it's

221.text:
a much less romantic document, part typed
and part closely penned into the little boxes

226.text:
of a Borough of Kensington Council form. And
here, again, you can see how unreliable apparently

233.text:
factual forms can be. Her name is now Christine
Granville. In fact, very little on here is true.

240.text:
The one I like best is occupation. It's got
down there 'former wife', but I can think

245.text:
of many words to describe Christine Granville
but they're not the two that spring to mind first.

250.text:
And her age is given as 37, although this
document is correctly dated 1952,

255.text:
so I know she should have been 44 years old. In fact, 
the only thing that's really strictly accurate

261.text:
on here is her cause of death and date of
death, and we're going to come to that later on.

265.text:
But somewhere between Warsaw and London, between
1908 and 1952, between life and death really,

272.text:
she has changed her name and her nationality.
She has left two husbands and numerous lovers behind.

278.text:
She has won international honours at the highest
level, but she has completely

282.text:
buried her career and she has cut seven years
from her life altogether. Well, I can't tell

286.text:
all the stories, but I'm going to tell you
the story of how she lost those seven years.

290.text:
So, when Germany invaded Poland in September
1939, Christine wasn't at home. She was actually

297.text:
in southern Africa with her second husband
who was a diplomat and they were out on his service.

303.text:
And when they heard, they turned around and
decided to come back to fight for

306.text:
their country or offer their services. But
it was a terrible story. They took the first

310.text:
passenger ship they could from southern Africa
and sailed to England. And, apparently, there was

316.text:
a noticeboard on that ship - this is her husband's 
unpublished memoirs tell this story -

320.text:
and it was from the captain and it advised
passengers of news. And one morning it said

324.text:
on that noticeboard it said, 'Lost: One ladies
pair of panties.' And underneath it said,

330.text:
'Lost: Warsaw.' And he said, 'This is perhaps
satirical English humour.'

336.text:
But this is how they found out about the loss
of their capital - appalling.

339.text:
Anyhow, by the time they arrived back in Europe,
Poland had fallen. So, they went on and disembarked

344.text:
in Southampton and within a couple of weeks
Christine has found and marched into the apparently

351.text:
secret headquarters of the British Secret
Services and basically demanded to be taken on.

357.text:
I mean this on its own is quite extraordinary.
Here she was - she was a foreigner, she was

361.text:
part-Jewish and, perhaps most shockingly of
all, she was a woman.

365.text:
Most people, of course, were recruited...
I mean this is before SOE [Special Operations Executive],

368.text:
two years before SOE was set up. It was Section D
 - D for destruction -

373.text:
and most people were recruited through the
old boy's network. So, it was extraordinary for her.

378.text:
And she had thought up a plan and they thought
it was brilliant and they took her on.

382.text:
In fact, I found the first British memo that
related to her in the archives in Kew and

387.text:
it describes her as 'a flaming Polish patriot,
an expert skier and a great adventuress' and

394.text:
it finishes that she is 'absolutely fearless'.
Well, that's rather wonderful,

398.text: but I think it is also pretty accurate.

400.text:
And so, here she is. She is now in Budapest.
This is taken, we believe, around January 1941

406.text:
and she's tickling a cat, very happy. It looks
like a holiday snap really, but she's

412.text:
actually been working undercover as Britain's
first special agent in Budapest for over a year

418.text:
when this photograph was taken and she has
undertaken four perilous missions into Warsaw,

424.text:
skiing over the High Tatra mountains. The
first trip is in winter and conditions are -20C.

429.text:
And the first time she went in she actually
skied past the bodies of people who

433.text:
were trying to get out who had frozen to death,
huddled together under the pines above Zakopane.

439.text:
So, incredibly courageous. And what she was
doing was taking in information and money

446.text:
for the fledgling Polish resistance that was
starting up - and she was there from January 1940,

451.text:
so very early on - and bringing out again,
mostly hidden inside her gloves, microfilm

457.text:
and also radio codes and that sort of thing.
And she established the first contact between

462.text:
the British and one of the biggest independent
Polish resistance groups.

466.text:
So, when she skied back, she would go into
Budapest. And she had a big network of British

475.text:
agent contacts out there, many of whom were
journalists - she was posing as a journalist

479.text:
as well - but she quickly made contact as
well with some of the Poles, including this

483.text:
rather handsome man whose name is Andrzej
Kowerski.

487.text:
Now, when the Nazis had invaded Poland, Andrzej
had volunteered in what was known as the Black Brigade,

493.text:
which was Poland's only mechanised division.
And they were called the Black Brigade

497.text:
because they wore these black leather jackets
- I should imagine he looked quite nice in

501.text:
a black leather jacket officer's uniform.
But he joined the motorised division as a boy.

508.text:
He had always loved horses and he had wanted
to be in the cavalry, but unfortunately

512.text:
a couple of years before the war a friend
of his at the family estate had accidentally

516.text:
shot Andrzej's foot off and it had to be amputated
to the knee. So, this gentleman only had one leg,

522.text:
so he couldn't ride a horse, so he joined
the mechanised division.

524.text: It didn't seem to hold him back at all.

527.text:
Paddy Leigh Fermor, just before he died sadly,
related this story that apparently the Germans

533.text:
were moving forward, their Panzer divisions,
and Andrzej was leading the Black Brigade

536.text:
- or a unit of them - and trying to hold them
back. And there was a big explosion, and dust

542.text:
and dirt blew up in the air. And, when it
all cleared, the Panzers had fallen back and

547.text:
Andrzej was pinned underneath an overturned
vehicle. And one of his unit came running

551.text:
down screaming for help, 'Get a doctor! Get
a medic! Andrzej is down!'

556.text:
I can't do the accents sadly or... I can't
even do Paddy doing the accent. But Andrzej said,

560.text:
'I don't need a doctor, you blithering idiot.
I need a blacksmith,' because he was just pinned

566.text:
down by the metal bit of his false leg and
he just needed to get it off and get the other one -

569.text:
he had a spare which he used to carry on his
back.

572.text:
So, he was quite remarkable. But eventually
he was pushed back across the border and eventually

578.text:
he was interned in an internment camp in Hungary
under the Geneva Convention.

583.text:
Now, he knew a lot about cars and one day
in the camp he spotted an Opel Olympia, which

588.text:
was the car of choice for discerning Wehrmacht officers. 
And so, he got in and somehow he hotwired it

594.text:
- how you do - and he drove himself out of
the camp. But, just as he was nearing the gates,

597.text:
he decided to turn back. He went and collected
the rest of his unit and drove out again.

603.text:
And he was actually awarded the Virtuti Militari
for his great work in Poland,

609.text:
which is Poland's highest award for valour.
So, an extraordinary gentleman.

613.text:
And there is a wonderful story that when Christine
first arrived in Budapest and she met Andrzej,

618.text:
he was telling stories of his adventures to
this adoring audience in the smoky basement

623.text:
of a Budapest bar, when he later said, 'The
door opened and a girl walked in.

628.text:
She was slim and sunburnt with brown hair and 
eyes, and a kind of crackling vitality seemed to

633.text:
emanate from her.' Well, that girl of course
was Christine and before the night was out

639.text:
she had invited him out for dinner. And so
it went on. They were lovers, but they were

643.text:
also colleagues in arms and they did some
amazing work together.

647.text:
And Christine helped run Andrzej's escape
routes. When he got his unit out into Budapest,

653.text:
most of them went on to rejoin their forces
in Northern Africa and his unit leader told

659.text:
him to stay because he obviously had a bit
of a gift for moving people out of the camps

663.text:
and he was down to do exfiltration. So, that
was anything... it was basically an early

667.text:
escape line route. And Christine had various
papers and so on, so she would help him with that.

673.text:
The British estimate that they helped to bring
out several thousand Polish prisoners of war,

678.text:
including many pilots. And - as you are probably
aware, being here today - the two squadrons

683.text:
in the Battle of Britain that had the highest
number of kills were the two Polish squadrons.

687.text: So, that in itself was work of huge importance.

690.text:
And Andrzej would help Christine with her
work as well, smuggling information around.

693.text:
Apparently, he whittled a hole in the wooden
part of his false leg and hid information in that.

700.text:
But Andrzej's wooden leg meant he couldn't
do everything Christine could. He couldn't

704.text:
ride, of course, and also he couldn't ski.
So, for her first trip across the mountains

709.text:
into Poland he arranged for an old friend
of his to guide her, and that happened to be

715.text:
- rather handily - the pre-war Polish Olympic
skiing champion. So, that was good.

719.text:
So, in she went. But she came back with someone
else and here he is. A rather wonderful looking character,

725.text:
this is Count Wladimir Ledóchowski - 
I'm sorry for the pronunciation -

732.text:
and he was an intelligence courier for 
the Polish government in exile,

737.text: which had now been established in Paris.

738.text:
He was also soon thrown together with her
in occupied Poland - they made the

744.text:
most of their time in every way. And the next
trip they took out together.

748.text:
Well, actually Christine had heard... she
had come out with Wladimir and then Andrzej

753.text:
was waiting for her, so that was fairly complicated.
And then she heard from the British that her

757.text:
husband had also joined the British Special
Services and was going to be posted to Budapest.

761.text:
So, then she said, 'I'm sure there's another
mission for me to go back into Poland.'

767.text:
And she went back again with Wladimir here.
And they crossed the border under fire,

772.text:
but managed to go inland. And it was now spring
and very rainy and the rivers were all swollen

778.text:
with floodwater and they were absolutely drenched.
And eventually that evening they decided to

783.text:
follow a branch line and take shelter under
an overhang on a platform, which was a mistake

789.text:
because the stationmaster saw them and came
out and said, 'What's going on here?'

794.text:
So, they said they were going the other way
and escaping, and they had got a story but

797.text:
he didn't really believe them. And he said, 'I'm
going to take you down to the police station.'

800.text:
And he called a couple of guards to go with
them.

802.text:
So, now they thought, 'Well, we're going to
be searched.' And they were carrying some

806.text:
very incriminating documents - incriminating
for them, but also for the people that they

809.text:
were going to connect to - so they had to
get rid of them. So, as they crossed a high bridge,

814.text:
between them they managed to throw this package
of documents into the river and

817.text:
it was washed away. So, that was good. But
clearly, now, they were up to something and

822.text:
so the guard said, 'Right, you stay here with
the policeman. I'm going to get the SS [Schutzstaffel]

827.text:
and, you dogs, they're going to get the story
out of you.'

830.text:
So, they were left there waiting under guard
and Wladimir at this point was... I mean they

835.text:
were under no illusions of what was going
to happen. They had had to hand over all their

839.text:
bags and he was fingering some cyanide powder
in his pocket and his great concern was how

843.text:
he could share that with Christine before
taking some himself.

849.text:
But Christine's thoughts were working along
a different direction. She had seen that the

853.text:
guards were going through everything in the
bags and laying stuff out on the wet grass,

857.text:
except every time they came to a different
package or a different bundle of money in

860.text:
a different denomination they would distribute
it between them and pocket it. So, she thought,

864.text:
'They've got another motive here: it's not
just politics, it's money involved.'

867.text:
So, she was wearing underneath her shirt a
beautiful cut-glass necklace that Wladimir

872.text:
had given her as a love token. And she leant
forward, as if nervously and distracted,

875.text:
and started saying, 'Oh, my diamonds, my diamonds!'
and pulling this necklace about. And the guards thought,

881.text:
'Oh, gosh!' and flipped up the torch to look
at them. And as they did so she broke

885.text:
the string so the diamonds tumbled into the
wet grass. And they swung the torch down to

890.text:
catch where these beads had gone. And Wladimir
took the opportunity to knock the torch out

894.text:
of their hand and they legged it for the trees.
And they managed to get into the pine forest,

898.text:
apparently, just before the bullets came whizzing
over their heads. And, amazingly, they did get away.

903.text:
Wladimir always said that Christine saved
his life at that moment, and I think

907.text:
they probably saved themselves. And they made
their way back to Budapest.

911.text:
Unfortunately, of course, their papers had
been taken, including photographs of Christine.

916.text:
And, apparently, her face was up in all the
Polish train stations soon afterwards.

921.text:
So, their cover had been broken. And when
they got back to Budapest, Andrzej - here he is,

927.text:
still waiting for Christine... and there they
are together. And Wladimir went on and fought

931.text:
in North Africa, where he was awarded the
Virtuti Militari as well,

935.text: and Christine went back to Andrzej.

936.text:
Now, Andrzej hadn't been idle whilst Christine
had been away. He had actually been arrested

941.text:
three times in that period by the Hungarian
police. And he had good contacts and they

946.text:
let him go. But the last time they said, 'You
have to leave the country. They're onto you,

950.text:
we can't let you go again.' But he insisted
on waiting for Christine. And, when she came back,

955.text:
she was very disheartened, but also she had
contracted a terrible flu from the

959.text:
conditions and was coughing and sneezing,
and she hadn't picked up the microfilm she

963.text:
was meant to collect. So, she said, 'Let's
just stay one day, maybe one night, maybe

968.text:
a courier can come out, I'll feel stronger
and we can go on then.' And Andrzej agreed.

972.text:
Again, I'm afraid, another mistake, because
that night, at 4 o'clock in the morning,

977.text:
the preferred calling hour for the Gestapo,
there was a banging on the door and they looked

983.text:
at each other. Apparently, in one of the stories
as it is told, apparently, Christine reached

988.text:
for her negligee, Andrzej grabbed his leg
and as they put them both on the door broke open

993.text:
and these four officers entered the room and
arrested them. Now, Andrzej looked at

998.text:
Christine thinking, 'Gosh, the girl is already
ill.' They knew what was going to happen - interrogation,

1002.text:
probably quite brutal - and he was very surprised
because apparently he said later,

1006.text:
'She thrived on danger and she looked as merry
as if she was going to a cocktail party,

1011.text: like now the fun is going to begin.'

1013.text:
So, they were taken away and they were interrogated
in different rooms in the police station.

1019.text:
Andrzej was beaten around the face and in
the kidneys and he was shown the bloodied

1023.text:
body of a man in the next cell they had been
working on, and he was terrified about Christine.

1027.text:
They had a well rehearsed story. Christine
was in the next room, again being interrogated,

1032.text: and again it was her that got them out.

1035.text:
The British files... there's a memo and it
says that Christine showed great presence

1040.text:
of mind at this point. Well, I'll say she
did. What she did was... she was coughing

1045.text:
quite badly from her flu and she decided to
make a strength of this apparent weakness.

1050.text:
So, she bit her tongue so hard and so repeatedly
that it bled, and not just a little bit,

1056.text:
but quite copiously. So, as she coughed it
looked as though she was coughing up blood,

1060.text:
which is of course a symptom of TB (tuberculosis)
- and in 1941 there was no cure for TB.

1064.text:
I don't know if you know but it is carried
by waterborne droplets. So, basically, interrogation

1071.text:
and TB don't mix very well. So, the Germans
decided to throw her out. And believing that

1077.text:
Andrzej was probably infected already as her
lover, although not showing the symptoms,

1080.text:
they threw him out as well. They did put a
tail on them, but they were out and

1085.text:
Christine certainly saved their lives at that
point.

1087.text:
Now, they went back to their flat and, luckily,
there was a friend of theirs waiting for them

1093.text:
who realised, obviously, they had been arrested
and said, 'Right, what can we do to get you out of this?'.

1098.text:
There was a car waiting for them outside.
And so, what they decided was

1101.text:
that this friend would drive Andrzej's big
old Chevrolet, that he had been moving men

1105.text:
around in, and he did. And the guys in the
car followed him. And then Christine and Andrzej

1112.text:
got into the old Opel Olympia, which was hidden
in a dirty greenhouse around the back of the flat,

1116.text:
and made a break for it having shaken off
their tail. And they went round to the

1120.text:
first place they thought they could get some
help, which was the British Ministry.

1127.text:
This is a beautiful portrait, I think, of
Sir Owen O'Malley who was the British minster

1131.text:
at the time of the legation. And he had a
bit of a soft spot for Christine, anyhow.

1137.text:
And he said in his memoirs, 'Christine could
do anything with dynamite... Oh, except eat it.'

1143.text:
So, he was quite fond of her. And later I
found some beautiful letters he wrote to her.

1146.text:
I think they were quite paternalistic letters
about his loving regard for her which

1151.text:
'flew like the wings of a swan across mountains
and meadows' to her. So, he was very fond of her,

1156.text:
and he saw the state they were in and said
immediately, 'Yes, I will help get you out.'

1160.text:
'Perhaps,' he said, 'we can fold Christine up like 
a penknife in the back of the Embassy Chrysler.

1165.text:
We will put the pennants on and my chauffer
can drive her across the border.'

1168.text:
And then, apparently, he looked at Andrzej
and said, 'Well, you can take your

1170.text:
chances in the Opel behind.' He was less concerned
about Andrzej, I think.

1174.text:
Anyhow, the first job they had to do was to
provide them with temporary British passports.

1179.text:
So, Sir Owen is pressing them for all the details 
and the first thing they needed was new names,

1184.text:
so they chose names with their own initials.
Now, at this point Andrzej had only

1187.text:
two words of English and they were 'double
whiskey', which I quite like, so he chose

1193.text:
an Irish name, the name Andrew Kennedy that
he was known under a lot of the time after the war.

1199.text:
And Christine chose the more aristocratic
sounding Christine Granville,

1204.text:
and it also suited her because she spoke French
fluently, having been educated in a convent school,

1210.text:
but her English was very heavily accented,
so that kind of explained that away.

1214.text:
Now, Sir Owen was getting very nervous. He
knew that outside there were people searching

1218.text:
for his guests. So, he was pressing them for
their eye colour, their height and so on,

1223.text:
and he asked for their date of birth. So,
Andrzej reeled his date of birth off and then

1228.text:
he looked at Christine and Christine just
paused and looked at him and took a moment

1232.text:
and slightly took the opportunity to knock
seven years off her date of birth.

1236.text:
I think, perhaps, it is partly identity disguise
but I think it is also one of the perks of being

1241.text:
a female special agent, a little bit of female
vanity as well.

1245.text:
So, that's how the legendary Christine Granville
was created.

1249.text: But I'm just going to finish that last story.

1252.text:
Why had Christine risked both their lives
to wait for that last microfilm?

1256.text:
Well, she soon had that film hidden inside her 
gloves and was taking it off across more borders.

1261.text:
Andrzej had driven the Opel and Christine had been 
driven across the border into free Yugoslavia

1268.text:
and they came out and toasted their freedom
with Hungarian brandy and then they

1272.text:
went onto Belgrade where a couple of days
later Sir Owen joined them. Apparently, they

1276.text:
went out to a Serbian belly dancing bar - as
you do, to celebrate - and then they went on.

1281.text:
And Christine at some point - I think probably
in Sofia - picked up that microfilm and she

1287.text:
took it on across the border. They went on
in the car and arrived in... Oh no, she probably

1292.text:
picked it up out there in Belgrade and gave
it over in Yugoslavia, probably to this gentleman.

1297.text:
We're not quite sure, but I think that may
be Sir Aidan Crawley - or Aidan Crawley as

1300.text:
he was then, later an MP - but we don't know,
his eyes have been blacked out. And that's

1305.text:
Christine and Andrew with, of course, their
Opel.

1310.text:
That film that she took really had the potential

2550.text:
she tried to get the French resistance cell
she was with to come and break them out and

2553.text:
they said it was impossible and we need to
focus on the allied invasion at the south,

2557.text:
the liberation that was coming. So they refused
and so she just walked in on her own - well,

2561.text:
she cycled over - and demanded his release.
And I won't tell you how, but she got him

2566.text:
out literally hours before he was due to be
shot.

2575.text:
She also helped to arrange some supply drops
to the French resistance. The different coloured

2579.text:
parachutes show what was in the different
containers. And here we are - these are the

2584.text:
containers being picked up by the Maquis that
they liaised with in that part of France.

2587.text:
And this is one of my photos - I mean these
containers they open sideways like peapods

2591.text:
and they would have been full of guns or ammunition,
chocolate and cigarettes as well and they're

2597.text:
just left standing against walls in that part
of France now.

2601.text:
And this is Christine with her French colleagues.
And last time I showed this I was in

2605.text:
The Special Forces Club and a lady at the
back said, 'Oh, that's my father.'

2612.text:
And these are Christine's medals. She was
not just the first but the longest serving

2619.text:
female agent for Britain in the war and for
her huge contribution to the Allied war effort

2624.text:
and her outstanding courage she was awarded the 
George Medal, the OBE [Order of the British Empire],

2631.text:
and this one on the right with the green ribbon is the 
French honour of the Croix de Guerre with one star.

2636.text:
And at the bottom you see that wonderful array
of ribbons that I think any general

2639.text:
would have been proud of, this shows the different
theatres of the war in which she operated.

2644.text:
And yet she wasn't given the award that she
valued most highly, which was ongoing employment

2650.text:
worthy of her service and abilities, and even
automatic British citizenship.

2655.text:
Her temporary passport ran out towards the end of 
the war and there was no way that she could return

2661.text:
to a Russian-occupied Poland. Her mother had
been killed under the Nazis. Her brother actually

2670.text:
died within a year of the Soviet-backed regime
in Poland, having been arrested -

2676.text:
he contracted TB in a cell. So, there was
no way she could return.

2679.text:
I don't know if she knew this - I don't think
she knew this - but I found evidence that

2683.text:
the British at one point had actually traded
her and Andrzej's names with the NKVD -

2687.text:
who were the precursors of the KGB - in an
information swap earlier on. So, they knew

2693.text:
if she had gone back, I'm sure she would have 
been killed. So she couldn't go back.

2698.text:
And yet she is left in Cairo. The British
did dismiss her and gave her £100,

2702.text:
which wasn't insignificant in those days. But the 
last memo that relates to her simply states,

2708.text:
'She is no longer wanted.' That's how we treated
her. Not our finest moment, I fear.

2715.text:
Now seven years after the war, on 15 June
1952, Christine was murdered. I don't think

2722.text:
it's giving the game away. This is what she
is most famous for, which I think is appalling.

2728.text:
She was stabbed through the heart with a commando
knife, ironically, very much like the one

2732.text:
that she had carried herself throughout the war, and 
not far from here in her hotel in South Kensington.

2740.text:
She was buried under a handful of Polish soil
in London's Kensal Green Roman Catholic Cemetery

2747.text:
This is Andrzej paying his last respects - there
he is. And this gentleman is one of his cousins

2752.text:
and broad family cousins, Ludwig Popitille,
with whom Christine had actually worked on

2758.text:
managing to secure... well he brought a Polish
anti-tank rifle out of occupied Poland into Budapest

2763.text:
and she saved it from being taken away by
the Hungarian police. So, there they are

2771.text:
I think, ultimately, unable to protect Christine's
life, Andrzej dedicated a lot of the rest

2776.text:
of his life trying to protect her reputation
and that's why her story has been so hidden.

2781.text:
There is a possibility that just the day after,
the morning after she was killed, she was

2788.text:
due to fly out to join Andrzej and he told
his niece that they were going to be married.

2793.text:
So, a terribly tragic ending. And 30 years
later when Andrzej died, of cancer actually,

2800.text:
they were kind of reunited. This plaque here
covers Andrzej's ashes and he was interred

2807.text:
at the foot of her grave, which is rather
wonderful really.

2812.text:
As I said, all too often people, if they know
something about Christine Granville,

2817.text:
it's that she was murdered at the end of the war. 
And there's lots of conspiracy theories around it,

2821.text:
which obviously I do look at in the book.
But I think all too often women in the resistance

2827.text:
are remembered as tragically romantic figures
and I don't think that's right.

2835.text:
Perhaps the best known female special agent in this 
country is Charlotte Gray who (a) is fictional

2838.text:
and (b) Sebastian Faulkes has her going out
to try and find her lost boyfriend.

2843.text:
Well, that is not why these women went out.
They're really highly trained. They went out

2848.text:
they knew exactly what they were doing - 
very specific missions.

2852.text:
And even some of the wonderful real British
female agents, like the fabulous Violette Szabo

2858.text:
or Odette, perhaps they're most known for
their outstanding courage and, in Szabo's case,

2865.text:
for her paying the ultimate sacrifice. But
they are remembered for their courage

2871.text:
rather than for their achievements. And I
hope that if my book contributes anything

2877.text:
it will be to highlight both the role and the use - 
and the abuse - of Poland during the war,

2884.text:
and also to rebalance the view on the effectiveness
of female special agents.

2888.text:
It is only now that a lot of the files have
been released and I got more information under

2894.text:
the Freedom of Information Act, such as surrounding
her murder, that I think her story can be told in full.

2901.text:
And I hope that this book presents a more
balanced picture of a remarkable woman

2906.text:
who can only, I would argue, be seen in the
context of her country, although it often

2911.text:
excluded her, and in the context of her time,
although I think she was in many ways ahead

2915.text:
of her time. And I hope at least this book
catches some of the fierce independence and

2920.text:
the slight vulnerability of a woman who loved
and was loved by so many, and the courage

2926.text:
of this fiercely patriotic Pole whose greatest
tragedy, I think, was perhaps that she didn't

2931.text: live to see her country, Poland, free again.

2934.text:
It was a real honour for me and a great adventure
to research and write this story, and I hope

2939.text:
that you will enjoy it. Thank you very much
for listening to me.
